original_data.question:
A 27-year-old college student presents to his physician for constant fatigue. The patient states that for the past several weeks he has felt oddly fatigued and has struggled to complete his work. He is a foreign exchange student and is concerned he will fail out of his academic program. He has experienced some occasional nausea and vomiting which has caused him to lose weight. The patient is a first year college student, drinks alcohol regularly, smokes marijuana, and has unprotected sex with multiple partners. His temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 127/68 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Laboratory values are ordered as seen below.

Serum:
Na+: 139 mEq/L
Cl-: 100 mEq/L
K+: 4.3 mEq/L
HCO3-: 25 mEq/L
BUN: 20 mg/dL
Glucose: 99 mg/dL
Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL
Ca2+: 10.2 mg/dL
Total bilirubin: 2.0 mg/dL
AST: 85 U/L
ALT: 92 U/L

Urine
Color: Amber/brown
Marijuana: Positive
Amphetamines: Positive
Cocaine: Positive

The patient refuses an examination of his genitals. Which of the following is the best diagnostic test?

model_response:
The CAGE questions are a series of questions designed to assess an individual for potential substance abuse or dependence. The questions focus on:

– C – Have you ever felt you ought to Cut down on your substance use?
– A – Have you ever been Annoyed by people's criticism of your substance use?
– G – Have you ever felt Guilty about your substance use?
– E – Have you ever needed an Eye-opener drink (early morning drink to get going)?

A positive response to two or more of these questions suggests a high likelihood of substance use disorder.

Option B is not the best diagnostic test for this patient. A urethral swab and culture would be appropriate if there was a suspicion of a sexually transmitted disease.

Option C is not the best diagnostic test for this patient. A viral core antibody test is used to diagnose acute viral infections such as hepatitis A and B.

Option D is not the best diagnostic test for this patient. A viral surface antibody test is used to diagnose acute viral infections such as hepatitis A and B.

Option A is the best diagnostic test for this patient. The patient's history of alcohol and marijuana use, along with the physical examination findings of poor dentition and yellowing of the eyes (possibly due to fatty liver), suggest alcoholic hepatitis. The CAGE questions are a useful screening tool for detecting alcohol abuse.

###Answer: OPTION A IS CORRECT.</s><s>

A single serving of a beverage; any liquid suitable for drinking.
Inhaling and exhaling SMOKE from CANNABIS.
Sexual intercourse without the use of precautions to prevent conception or the transmission of sexually transmitted diseases.
The sexual union of a male and a female, a term used for human only.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A non-SI unit of pressure equal to 133,332 Pa or 1.316E10-3 standard atmosphere. Use of this unit is generally deprecated by ISO and IUPAC.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.

The act of breathing with the LUNGS, consisting of INHALATION, or the taking into the lungs of the ambient air, and of EXHALATION, or the expelling of the modified air which contains more CARBON DIOXIDE than the air taken in (Blakiston's Gould Medical Dictionary, 4th ed.). This does not include tissue respiration (= OXYGEN CONSUMPTION) or cell respiration (= CELL RESPIRATION).
Unmodified air as existing in the immediate surroundings.

Test results which deviate substantially from normal ranges of REFERENCE VALUES or other qualitative results. They trigger CLINICAL LABORATORY SERVICES to place a special alert to ensure PATIENT SAFETY.
The clear portion of BLOOD that is left after BLOOD COAGULATION to remove BLOOD CELLS and clotting proteins.
chief cation of the extracellular body fluids.
atom of potassium having a positive charge; potassium is the chief cation of muscle and most other cells (intracellular fluid).

Electroneutral chloride bicarbonate exchangers that allow the exchange of BICARBONATE IONS exchange for CHLORIDE IONS across the cellular membrane. The action of specific antiporters in this class serve important functions such as allowing the efficient exchange of bicarbonate across red blood cell membranes as they passage through capillaries and the reabsorption of bicarbonate ions by the kidney.

The urea concentration of the blood stated in terms of nitrogen content. Serum (plasma) urea nitrogen is approximately 12% higher than blood urea nitrogen concentration because of the greater protein content of red blood cells. Increases in blood or serum urea nitrogen are referred to as azotemia and may have prerenal, renal, or postrenal causes. (From Saunders Dictionary & Encyclopedia of Laboratory Medicine and Technology, 1984)
The breakdown product of creatine, a constituent of muscle tissue, that is excreted by the kidney and whose serum level is used to evaluate kidney function.
A bile pigment that is a degradation product of HEME.
Enzymes of the transferase class that catalyze the conversion of L-aspartate and 2-ketoglutarate to oxaloacetate and L-glutamate. EC 2.6.1.1.
An enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of L-alanine and 2-oxoglutarate to pyruvate and L-glutamate. (From Enzyme Nomenclature, 1992) EC 2.6.1.2.
Detection of cocaine or its major metabolite, benzoylecgonine, in urine. []
Involving advantage or good.
**Description:**The patient refused to take the product.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
The external and internal organs involved in the functions of REPRODUCTION.
heading term for tests not treed elsewhere under DIAGNOSIS.
